About us

We are a team of university students with the goal of increasing their knowledge by facing new challenges like this Space Apps Challenge. We have developed a fully functional website for the visualization of seismic data between expeditions to the moon in the Apollo Space Program.

About the project

Since first moon landing, several geophysical data was gathered which was improved on following missions From this data, we have seen deep and soft moonquakes with its own magnitudes. On this web we have shown the capabilities of the 3D model made by our team during the hackaton.

Scrool down to learn more about the project!

Firstly, some information about the different sources we have obtained to tackle the project.


EASEP

The Early Apollo Surface Experiments Package are solar-powered seismic measurement and transmission instruments.

View details

ALSEP

The Apollo Lunar Surface Experiments Package switches power generation to radioisotope thermoelectric generator and focuses on studying the lunar environment.

View details

APOLLO

And lastly, some information on the different moon missions.



View details

MoonquakeMap project. It’ll blow your mind.


Since the first lunar landing, we have data from different moonquakes obtained due to the instrumentation deployed by the different Apollo missions such as EASEP and ALSEP. With this data we have created a 3D representation of the moon in which exact points appear as a representation of the moonquakes of each year since there is a record of the magnitude. More information here.

More about the solution. See for yourself.


This is the application we have created. You can choose a year in the drop-down menu above and it will show you the seismic events of that year and their magnitude in a 3D model of the moon that you can move 360º and see the exact position in which they occurred.

And lastly, this one.

This video shows you a brief explanation of how the application works and what functionalities it offers.
